title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Goals for this Video
In this video:


filter out rows in a tidy way
Apply Boolean operators
slice and dice to find maxima and minima

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
filter
While select is used for column selection, filter is used for row selection

penguins |> filter(bill_length_mm > 40)


Similar syntax to select:

No need to quote column names
Data is first (piped) argument
Later arguments specify action

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
filter
Contrast

penguins |> filter(bill_length_mm > 40)

with

penguins[penguins$bill_length_mm > 40, ]

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
filter
Multiple filters give the intersection:

penguins |> filter(bill_length_mm > 40, sex == "female")


Use logical operators to get the union:

penguins |> filter(bill_length_mm > 40 | sex == "female")

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
filter
Pipes are very useful for multi-step operations

penguins |> filter(bill_length_mm > 40) |> select(species)


Compare to

select(filter(penguins, bill_length_mm > 40), species)

Piped form reads left to right instead of inside out

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
filter
Can use more complex comparisons in filter:

penguins |> filter(body_mass_g > mean(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))

# A tibble: 149 × 8
   species island    bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g
   <fct>   <fct>              <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int>
 1 Adelie  Torgersen           39.2          19.6               195        4675
 2 Adelie  Torgersen           42            20.2               190        4250
 3 Adelie  Torgersen           34.6          21.1               198        4400
 4 Adelie  Torgersen           42.5          20.7               197        4500
 5 Adelie  Dream               39.8          19.1               184        4650
 6 Adelie  Dream               44.1          19.7               196        4400
 7 Adelie  Dream               39.6          18.8               190        4600
 8 Adelie  Biscoe              40.1          18.9               188        4300
 9 Adelie  Biscoe              41.3          21.1               195        4400
10 Adelie  Torgersen           41.8          19.4               198        4450
# ℹ 139 more rows
# ℹ 2 more variables: sex <fct>, year <int>



What would happen without na.rm=TRUE?

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
filter
Common mistake - using only a single equals sign for equality

penguins |> filter(sex = "female")

Error in `filter()`:
! We detected a named input.
ℹ This usually means that you've used `=` instead of `==`.
ℹ Did you mean `sex == "female"`?

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
slice functions
The slice_* family extend filter:

penguins |> slice_max(body_mass_g, n=1)

# A tibble: 1 × 8
  species island bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g
  <fct>   <fct>           <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int>
1 Gentoo  Biscoe           49.2          15.2               221        6300
# ℹ 2 more variables: sex <fct>, year <int>



Equivalent to:

penguins |> filter(body_mass_g == max(body_mass_g, na.rm=TRUE))

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
slice functions
Standard slices:

slice_min
slice_max
slice_head
slice_tail


Can specify:

n= to get top/bottom \(n\)
prop= to select a fraction

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
filter extensions
slice_sample: random subset of your data

Useful if exploring a large data set


penguins |> slice_sample(n=10)

# A tibble: 10 × 8
   species   island   bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g
   <fct>     <fct>             <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int>
 1 Adelie    Torgers…           37.2          19.4               184        3900
 2 Adelie    Biscoe             37.9          18.6               193        2925
 3 Gentoo    Biscoe             52.1          17                 230        5550
 4 Chinstrap Dream              51.3          19.2               193        3650
 5 Adelie    Torgers…           35.7          17                 189        3350
 6 Gentoo    Biscoe             59.6          17                 230        6050
 7 Gentoo    Biscoe             45.7          13.9               214        4400
 8 Chinstrap Dream              46            18.9               195        4150
 9 Adelie    Torgers…           35.9          16.6               190        3050
10 Gentoo    Biscoe             45.2          16.4               223        5950
# ℹ 2 more variables: sex <fct>, year <int>

Goals for this Video
In this video:


Introduce the concept of Tidy Data
Identify Key Aspects of Tidy Data
Learn to Diagnose Non-Tidy Data

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Data Frames in R
data.frame - R’s tabular data storage

library(palmerpenguins)
head(penguins)

  species    island bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g
1  Adelie Torgersen           39.1          18.7               181        3750
2  Adelie Torgersen           39.5          17.4               186        3800
3  Adelie Torgersen           40.3          18.0               195        3250
4  Adelie Torgersen             NA            NA                NA          NA
5  Adelie Torgersen           36.7          19.3               193        3450
6  Adelie Torgersen           39.3          20.6               190        3650
     sex year
1   male 2007
2 female 2007
3 female 2007
4   <NA> 2007
5 female 2007
6   male 2007

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Data Frames in R
palmerpenguins


344 penguins observed on the Palmer Islands (Antarctica)
3 species, 3 islands, 3 years
4 numeric variables
One categorial (factor) variable (sex)

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Data Frames in R
Key features:


Tabular (rows and columns) structure
Entries in the same column are all of the same type
Columns may be different types

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Data Frames in R
Can be manipulated using standard R syntax:

table(penguins[penguins$bill_length_mm > 40, "species"])


   Adelie Chinstrap    Gentoo 
       51        68       123 




$ extracts a column as a vector
df[row index, column index]

Logical row indexing to select rows where bill_length_mm > 40
Column indexing by name to select a single column

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
What is Tidy Data?
“Tidy Data”:

Principles to make data manipulation safe and easy
Decrease chance of errors
Increase productivity


What does it mean to be tidy?


Everything in its proper place

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Tidy Data
Recall our penguins:


  species bill_length_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g    sex
1  Adelie           39.1               181        3750   male
2  Adelie           39.5               186        3800 female
3  Adelie           40.3               195        3250 female
4  Adelie             NA                NA          NA   <NA>
5  Adelie           36.7               193        3450 female
6  Adelie           39.3               190        3650   male



Key features:


Each row is one observation (🐧)
Each column has one and only one fact
All values are in the table

Not hiding in row and column names

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Tidy Data


Figure from R for Data Science by H. Wickham

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Tidy - Why?
Why emphasize tidy data?

Minimize distractions:

Free to focus on analysis not code



Once data is “tidy”, you can focus on the real questions


First goal for data pre-processing (“tidying up”)

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Tidy - Who (and When)?
The name and principles of “tidy data” were popularized by H. Wickham (2014)

Core ideas are much older, dating back to (at least) Codd’s Relational Model in the 1970s, now ubiquitous in relational databases (SQL)


Now found in:

Python (pandas)
Julia (DataFrames)
Rust (polars)
and more

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Tidy - How (and Where)?
tidyverse - Packages for Manipulating Tidy Data:


ggplot2: Visualization
dplyr: SQL-like operations
tidyr: Reshaping and cleaning data
readr: Ingest tidy data into R
Tidy manipulation of different data types:

stringr, forcats, lubridate




More helpers in the background (tibble, vctrs, …)

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Aside: tibbles
You will sometimes see tibble (tbl_df) as a synonym for data.frame

Minor differences in output formatting
Fewer edge cases

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Some Untidy Examples
Baruch college business core enrollment:


# A tibble: 6 × 4
  Semester Course     Enrollment   Cap
  <chr>    <chr>           <dbl> <dbl>
1 Fall     Accounting        200   250
2 Fall     Law               100   125
3 Fall     Statistics        200   200
4 Spring   Accounting        300   350
5 Spring   Law                50   100
6 Spring   Statistics        400   400



Tidy! ✅



Each row is one unit (a class) 👍
Columns are well-typed 👍
One piece of information per column 👍

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Some Untidy Examples


# A tibble: 6 × 3
  Semester Course     Enrollment  
  <chr>    <chr>      <chr>       
1 Fall     Accounting "200 of 250"
2 Fall     Law        "100 of 125"
3 Fall     Statistics "200 of 200"
4 Spring   Accounting "300 of 350"
5 Spring   Law        " 50 of 100"
6 Spring   Statistics "400 of 400"



Untidy! ❌


Multiple pieces of information per cell (Enrollment)

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Some Untidy Examples


# A tibble: 12 × 4
   Semester Course     Number Type      
   <chr>    <chr>       <dbl> <chr>     
 1 Fall     Accounting    200 Enrollment
 2 Fall     Accounting    250 Cap       
 3 Fall     Law           100 Enrollment
 4 Fall     Law           125 Cap       
 5 Fall     Statistics    200 Enrollment
 6 Fall     Statistics    200 Cap       
 7 Spring   Accounting    300 Enrollment
 8 Spring   Accounting    350 Cap       
 9 Spring   Law            50 Enrollment
10 Spring   Law           100 Cap       
11 Spring   Statistics    400 Enrollment
12 Spring   Statistics    400 Cap       



Untidy! ❌


Mixing two pieces of information (Enrollments and Caps)
Tip: When one unit spans multiple rows, likely untidy

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Some Untidy Examples


# A tibble: 6 × 3
  Semester Course     Enrollment
  <chr>    <chr>           <dbl>
1 Fall     Accounting        200
2 Fall     Law               100
3 Fall     Statistics        200
# ℹ 3 more rows


and


# A tibble: 6 × 3
  Semester Course       Cap
  <chr>    <chr>      <dbl>
1 Fall     Accounting   250
2 Fall     Law          125
3 Fall     Statistics   200
# ℹ 3 more rows



Untidy! ❌


Data spread across multiple columns

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Looking Ahead
For now, we’ll provide you with tidy data

Upcoming topics:


Visualizing Tidy Data (Week 3)
Statistical Models of Tidy Data (Week 4)
Manipulating Tidy Data (Week 5)
Taking Untidy Web Data and Making it Tidy (Week 7)

title: STA 9750 - OSMBA - Course Learning Objectives
text: This course provides an understanding of the principles and concepts of using computer tools for data analysis and visualization. Students will learn to use a scientific programming language (such as R) to import and export data from and into spreadsheets or other statistical software packages. They will gain experience in analyzing both quantitative and qualitative data, and statistical modelling techniques will be introduced. Written reports will prepare students for clear communication of their analysis in professional settings. This course is designed primarily for Masters’ students in statistics and quantitative methods and modeling (QMM), and those interested in carrying out sophisticated statistical analyses of data using statistical software.

title: STA 9750 - OSMBA - Course Learning Objectives
text: This course provides an understanding of the principles and concepts of using computer tools for data analysis and visualization. Students will learn to use a scientific programming language (such as R) to import and export data from and into spreadsheets or other statistical software packages. They will gain experience in analyzing both quantitative and qualitative data, and statistical modelling techniques will be introduced. Written reports will prepare students for clear communication of their analysis in professional settings. This course is designed primarily for Masters’ students in statistics and quantitative methods and modeling (QMM), and those interested in carrying out sophisticated statistical analyses of data using statistical software.

title: STA 9750 - OSMBA - Course Learning Objectives
text:
Program Learning Goals
This course contributes to the program learning goals of several MS programs offered by the Zicklin School of Business.

MS in Business Analytics
This course contributes to the following Program Learning Goals for the MS in Business Analytics:

MSBA Program Learning Goals







STA 9750 - OSMBA Learning Goal
MSBA Learning Goal
Description




✓
Data Management
Students will be able to apply methods, tools, and software for acquiring, managing/storing, and accessing structured and unstructured data. Students will also demonstrate knowledge of the strategic uses of data.


✓
Foundational Statistical / Quantitative Skills
Students will be able to prepare data for statistical analysis, perform basic exploratory and descriptive analysis as well as employ foundational statistical techniques needed to analyze data.


✓
Advanced Statistical/Quantitative Skills
Students will be able to build and interpret advanced predictive models. Students will be able to combine business rules and mathematical models to optimize business decisions from data.



Ethical Awareness
Students will be able to articulate an understanding of ethical issues in all phases of business analytics with particular emphasis on the new possibilities afforded by the emergence of big data.


✓
Professional Communication
Students will be able to explain complex analytical models and their results orally and in writing to technical and non technical/lay audiences.


✓
Knowledge Integration
Students will be able to apply the three key types of analytics (descriptive, predictive, and prescriptive) in a business domain to add value to business decision-making.





MS in Quantitative Methods & Modeling
This course contributes to the following Program Learning Goals for the MS in Quantitative Methods & Modeling:

MSQMM Program Learning Goals







STA 9750 - OSMBA Learning Goal
MSQMM Learning Goal
Description




✓
Operations Research & Mathematical Modeling
Students will be able to effectively model, evaluate, and solve quantitative (business) problems using quantitative modeling methods (e.g. deterministic and probabilistic operations research techniques).


✓
Statistics
Students will be able to correctly apply appropriate statistical methods when defining, solving, and analyzing problems.


✓
Technology Competency
Students will be able to use current technological tools, including spreadsheets and specialized software, when solving problems.


✓
Professional Communication
Students will be able to effectively communicate their problem solving methods and solutions to technical and non-technical audiences.





MS in Statistics
This course contributes to the following Program Learning Goals for the MS in Statistics:

MS Statistics Program Learning Goals







STA 9750 - OSMBA Learning Goal
MS Stat Learning Goal
Description




✓
General Statistical Competence
Students will be able to apply appropriate probability models and statistical techniques when analyzing problems from business and other fields.


✓
Statistical Practice
Students will become familiar with the standard tools of statistical practice for multiple regression, along with the tools of a subset of specialized statistical areas such as multivariate analysis, applied sampling, time series analysis, experimental design, data mining, categorical analysis, and/or stochastic processes.


✓
Technology Competency
Students will learn to use one or more of the benchmark statistical software platforms, such as SAS or R.

title: Welcome
text:
Welcome to the offering of STA 9750 - OSMBA as a part of the Online MSBA at Zicklin School of Business, Baruch College CUNY.
For now, this shell holds only slides for recording of course materials. It will eventually host extended worked examples, supplemental data sets, and interactive activities.

text:

Tidy Row Selection
Tidy Column Manipulation
Groupwise Operations

Joining Multiple Tables
Reshaping Tidy Data
Basic Statistical Analysis
Installing python
python Basics: Syntax
python Basics: Control Flow
python Basics: Objects
python Basics: Control Flow

More will be added later.

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Goals for this Video
In this video:


Introduce the dplyr package and the pipe operator (|>)
select and rename columns in a tidy way
Use advanced selectors for groups of columns

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Tidy Data
Recall our definition of “tidy” data - everything in its proper place:


One and only one type of information per column
One and only one observation per row
No values ‘hiding’ in column or row names



Return of the palmerpenguins:


# A tibble: 344 × 3
  species island    bill_length_mm
  <fct>   <fct>              <dbl>
1 Adelie  Torgersen           39.1
2 Adelie  Torgersen           39.5
# ℹ 342 more rows

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Tidy Tools for Tidy Data
tidyverse - Tools for manipulating tidy data

Make sure to load the tidyverse package before using

library(tidyverse)

── Attaching core tidyverse packages ──────────────────────── tidyverse 2.0.0 ──
✔ dplyr     1.1.4     ✔ readr     2.1.5
✔ forcats   1.0.0     ✔ stringr   1.5.1
✔ ggplot2   3.5.1     ✔ tibble    3.2.1
✔ lubridate 1.9.4     ✔ tidyr     1.3.1
✔ purrr     1.0.4     
── Conflicts ────────────────────────────────────────── tidyverse_conflicts() ──
✖ dplyr::filter() masks stats::filter()
✖ dplyr::lag()    masks stats::lag()
ℹ Use the conflicted package (<http://conflicted.r-lib.org/>) to force all conflicts to become errors


Safe to ignore messages about conflicts

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
tidyverse Packages





tidyverse tools have excellent documentation

Visit tidyverse.org for overall information
Individual packages: ggplot2.tidyverse.org, dplyr.tidyverse.org, etc.



Function Reference - Details of specific functions
Vignettes / Articles - Big picture tutorials

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
dplyr
You have already seen one tidyverse package: ggplot2

Today we start with dplyr - ‘grammar of data manipulation’

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
select
The select function can be used to select certain columns

select(penguins, species, bill_length_mm, body_mass_g, sex)

# A tibble: 344 × 4
   species bill_length_mm body_mass_g sex   
   <fct>            <dbl>       <int> <fct> 
 1 Adelie            39.1        3750 male  
 2 Adelie            39.5        3800 female
 3 Adelie            40.3        3250 female
 4 Adelie            NA            NA <NA>  
 5 Adelie            36.7        3450 female
 6 Adelie            39.3        3650 male  
 7 Adelie            38.9        3625 female
 8 Adelie            39.2        4675 male  
 9 Adelie            34.1        3475 <NA>  
10 Adelie            42          4250 <NA>  
# ℹ 334 more rows



Arguments: data => columns we want

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
select
Contrast

select(penguins, species, bill_length_mm, body_mass_g, sex)

with

penguins[,c("species", "bill_length_mm", "body_mass_g", "sex")]



Key differences:

No quotes around column names
Pass names as arguments, not 1 vector

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Put that in your Pipe
R supports piped operations - feeding the output of one function into another

select(penguins, species, bill_length_mm, body_mass_g, sex)

is equivalent to

penguins |> select(species, bill_length_mm, body_mass_g, sex)


Read |> as “and then”
dplyr plays very nicely with pipes

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
select
Like vector indexing, negative sign drops columns:

penguins |> select(-species)

# A tibble: 344 × 7
   island bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g sex    year
   <fct>           <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int> <fct> <int>
 1 Torge…           39.1          18.7               181        3750 male   2007
 2 Torge…           39.5          17.4               186        3800 fema…  2007
 3 Torge…           40.3          18                 195        3250 fema…  2007
 4 Torge…           NA            NA                  NA          NA <NA>   2007
 5 Torge…           36.7          19.3               193        3450 fema…  2007
 6 Torge…           39.3          20.6               190        3650 male   2007
 7 Torge…           38.9          17.8               181        3625 fema…  2007
 8 Torge…           39.2          19.6               195        4675 male   2007
 9 Torge…           34.1          18.1               193        3475 <NA>   2007
10 Torge…           42            20.2               190        4250 <NA>   2007
# ℹ 334 more rows

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
select
: operator selects a range of columns

penguins |> select(bill_length_mm:body_mass_g)

# A tibble: 344 × 4
   bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm body_mass_g
            <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>       <int>
 1           39.1          18.7               181        3750
 2           39.5          17.4               186        3800
 3           40.3          18                 195        3250
 4           NA            NA                  NA          NA
 5           36.7          19.3               193        3450
 6           39.3          20.6               190        3650
 7           38.9          17.8               181        3625
 8           39.2          19.6               195        4675
 9           34.1          18.1               193        3475
10           42            20.2               190        4250
# ℹ 334 more rows


You can also use c here

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
select
select also supports several “smart” helpers to pick columns

penguins |> select(contains("bill"))

# A tibble: 344 × 2
   bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm
            <dbl>         <dbl>
 1           39.1          18.7
 2           39.5          17.4
 3           40.3          18  
 4           NA            NA  
 5           36.7          19.3
 6           39.3          20.6
 7           38.9          17.8
 8           39.2          19.6
 9           34.1          18.1
10           42            20.2
# ℹ 334 more rows

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
select
See ?dplyr_tidy_select for more helpers

penguins |> select(ends_with("mm"))

# A tibble: 344 × 3
   bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm flipper_length_mm
            <dbl>         <dbl>             <int>
 1           39.1          18.7               181
 2           39.5          17.4               186
 3           40.3          18                 195
 4           NA            NA                  NA
 5           36.7          19.3               193
 6           39.3          20.6               190
 7           38.9          17.8               181
 8           39.2          19.6               195
 9           34.1          18.1               193
10           42            20.2               190
# ℹ 334 more rows

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
select
Helpers can be combined using & (intersection) and | (union) operations:

penguins |> select(contains("bill") | ends_with("g"))

# A tibble: 344 × 3
   bill_length_mm bill_depth_mm body_mass_g
            <dbl>         <dbl>       <int>
 1           39.1          18.7        3750
 2           39.5          17.4        3800
 3           40.3          18          3250
 4           NA            NA            NA
 5           36.7          19.3        3450
 6           39.3          20.6        3650
 7           38.9          17.8        3625
 8           39.2          19.6        4675
 9           34.1          18.1        3475
10           42            20.2        4250
# ℹ 334 more rows

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
select
Predicate operator can select columns based on properties of values

penguins |> select(where(is.numeric))


Also: is.character and is.factor


Can be extended to more complex checks:

Pass a custom function
(Not covered here; see docs for examples)

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
select
where combines nicely with other selectors:

penguins |> select(where(is.numeric) & ends_with("mm"))

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
rename
Use rename to change column names:

penguins |> 
    select(where(is.numeric) & ends_with("mm")) |>
    rename(`Bill Length (mm)`=bill_length_mm, 
           `Bill Depth (mm)`=bill_depth_mm,
           `Flipper Length (mm)`=flipper_length_mm)






Bill Length (mm)
Bill Depth (mm)
Flipper Length (mm)




39.1
18.7
181


39.5
17.4
186


40.3
18.0
195


NA
NA
NA


36.7
19.3
193


39.3
20.6
190







Particularly useful for formatting output

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
rename
rename tips:


Use backticks (`) to surround ‘non-syntactic’ names
Useful to make names useful R variables pre-analysis
Useful to make names proper English post-analysis

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Goals for this Video
In this video:


mutate rows to safely transform data
Perform conditional transformations
Compute running and cumulative statistics
Apply simple aggregation and window functions

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
mutate
So far we have only subsetted our data. Can we create new columns?


penguins |> 
    mutate(body_mass_lb = body_mass_g / 453) |>
    select(contains("body"))

# A tibble: 344 × 2
   body_mass_g body_mass_lb
         <int>        <dbl>
 1        3750         8.28
 2        3800         8.39
 3        3250         7.17
 4          NA        NA   
 5        3450         7.62
 6        3650         8.06
 7        3625         8.00
 8        4675        10.3 
 9        3475         7.67
10        4250         9.38
# ℹ 334 more rows

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
mutate

penguins |> 
    mutate(body_mass_lb = body_mass_g / 453) |>
    select(contains("body"))

Similar syntax to select and filter

Put name on the left of the =
If you omit a name, unhelpful default:

penguins |> mutate(body_mass_g / 453) |> select(contains("body"))



# A tibble: 344 × 2
  body_mass_g `body_mass_g/453`
        <int>             <dbl>
1        3750              8.28
2        3800              8.39
3        3250              7.17
# ℹ 341 more rows

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
mutate
Can do arbitrary vectorized operations and access recently created columns:

penguins |> 
    select(where(is.numeric)) |>
    mutate(weight_kg = body_mass_g / 1000,
           height_m = body_height_mm / 1000, 
           bmi = weight_kg / height_m^2)

(Sadly, don’t actually have height data)

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
mutate helpers
?mutate lists several helpful functions:

if_else, case_when
cumsum, cummean
lead, lag
min_rank, dense_rank

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Complex Transforms
Use case_when for transforms that depend on other values:

penguins |>
  mutate(cuteness_level = 
    case_when(
        species == "Adelie" ~ "Exceptionally", 
        species == "Gentoo" ~ "Remarkably",
        species == "Chinstrap" ~ "Stunningly"
    )) |>
  select(species, cuteness_level, body_mass_g) |> 
  slice_head(n=5)

# A tibble: 5 × 3
  species cuteness_level body_mass_g
  <fct>   <chr>                <int>
1 Adelie  Exceptionally         3750
2 Adelie  Exceptionally         3800
3 Adelie  Exceptionally         3250
4 Adelie  Exceptionally           NA
5 Adelie  Exceptionally         3450

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Complex Transforms
case_when specifies a series of tests. First one passed is used:

case_when(
    test1 ~ value1, 
    test2 ~ value2
    ...
)

Use TRUE for default values

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Cumulative Stats
The cum* family of functions compute cumulative values

cummean
cummax, cummin
cumsum, cumprod


These depend on the order of the data
You may want to use arrange to order data first

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Cumulative Stats

penguins |>
    arrange(body_mass_g) |> # Defaults to increasing; use desc() to reverse
    mutate(average_mass = cummean(body_mass_g), 
           number_of_penguins = row_number()) |>
    select(species, 
           body_mass_g,
           average_mass,  
           number_of_penguins) |>
    slice_head(n=5)

# A tibble: 5 × 4
  species   body_mass_g average_mass number_of_penguins
  <fct>           <int>        <dbl>              <int>
1 Chinstrap        2700         2700                  1
2 Adelie           2850         2775                  2
3 Adelie           2850         2800                  3
4 Adelie           2900         2825                  4
5 Adelie           2900         2840                  5


Rolling statistics are a bit trickier - look into RcppRoll

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Ranking
To assign ranks, use the *_rank functions:

penguins |>
    mutate(body_mass_rank = min_rank(body_mass_g)) |>
    select(contains("body_mass")) |>
    slice_head(n=5)

# A tibble: 5 × 2
  body_mass_g body_mass_rank
        <int>          <int>
1        3750            121
2        3800            130
3        3250             29
4          NA             NA
5        3450             61



min_rank and dense_rank differ in treatment of ties

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Ranking
percent_rank and cume_dist for CDF-type ranking

penguins |>
    mutate(body_mass_pct_rank = round(percent_rank(body_mass_g), 2),
           body_mass_cdf      = round(cume_dist(body_mass_g), 2)) |>
    select(contains("body_mass")) |>
    slice_head(n=5)

# A tibble: 5 × 3
  body_mass_g body_mass_pct_rank body_mass_cdf
        <int>              <dbl>         <dbl>
1        3750               0.35          0.37
2        3800               0.38          0.41
3        3250               0.08          0.1 
4          NA              NA            NA   
5        3450               0.18          0.2 


CDF: cume_dist \(\leq\) vs percent_rank \(<\)

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:
Ranking
Use ntile to split data into quartiles, deciles, etc.

penguins |>
    mutate(body_mass_decile = ntile(body_mass_g, 10)) |>
    select(contains("body_mass")) |>
    slice_head(n=5)

# A tibble: 5 × 2
  body_mass_g body_mass_decile
        <int>            <int>
1        3750                4
2        3800                4
3        3250                1
4          NA               NA
5        3450                2

title: Software Tools for Data AnalysisSTA 9750Michael Weylandt
text:

Now it’s your turn!
Time to apply these tools to flights leaving NYC
